description: Can you create a chart from the Excel data for our report? Can you make a dashboard? Oh, we also need a pivot table.  These are requests that can make Excel users quiver in fear.  In this series, we simplify how to create charts, PivotTables, and PivotCharts. We start from the beginning with identifying terminology used with charts and advance to creating complex PivotTables and PivotCharts.
descriptionMD: Can you create a chart from the Excel data for our report? Can you make a dashboard? Oh, we also need a pivot table.  These are requests that can make Excel users quiver in fear.  In this series, we simplify how to create charts, PivotTables, and PivotCharts. We start from the beginning with identifying terminology used with charts and advance to creating complex PivotTables and PivotCharts.
name: Excel Charts and Pivot Tables
subtitle: Excel Charts and Pivot Tables

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne kick off the Excel Charts and Pivot tables series by building your foundational knowledge in regards to Charts. Here they will identify the parts of a Chart, define terms used, and look at the contextual tabs you'll use when working with Charts.
episodes.title: Introduction to Charts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.296 --> 00:00:14.532
All right, greetings, everyone, and

3

welcome to another great
episode of OfficeProTV.

4
00:00:17.377 --> 00:00:18.741
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:18.741 --> 00:00:20.427
And in today's episode, well,

6

we are starting our new series on
Excel charts and pivot tables.

7

And guess, what joining us in the studio
is our resident expert on that very topic.

8
00:00:27.405 --> 00:00:29.540
Our good friend, Ms. Vonne Smith.

9
00:00:29.540 --> 00:00:30.722
Vonne, we're glad to have
you in this new series.

10
00:00:30.722 --> 00:00:31.950
It's gonna be a lot of fun.

11
00:00:31.950 --> 00:00:33.393
How it's going today?

12
00:00:33.393 --> 00:00:36.136
>> It's a great day Here at ITProTV.

13
00:00:36.136 --> 00:00:38.300
[LAUGH]
>> We do have fun here, don't we?

14
00:00:38.300 --> 00:00:38.960
>> Yes, wait, we're OfficeProTv.

15
00:00:38.960 --> 00:00:39.777
>> Yeah.

16
00:00:39.777 --> 00:00:40.490
>> Yes.

17
00:00:40.490 --> 00:00:41.503
>> Same thing.
>> Well, we've got this here.

18
00:00:41.503 --> 00:00:42.123
>> Yeah, we're all [INAUDIBLE].

19
00:00:42.123 --> 00:00:44.582
>> It's all one big family.

20
00:00:44.582 --> 00:00:47.670
>> [LAUGH] Yes, and
we're exploring the family of charts and

21
00:00:47.670 --> 00:00:49.310
pivot tables in this series.

22
00:00:49.310 --> 00:00:53.152
This is our first in the series
that we're gonna start off with,

23
00:00:53.152 --> 00:00:55.725
just some basic foundational knowledge.

24
00:00:55.725 --> 00:01:00.190
Because we really wanna just separate
out the charts and the pivot tables.

25
00:01:00.190 --> 00:01:02.815
Because it seems that everybody wants
to know how to do a pivot table.

26
00:01:02.815 --> 00:01:04.550
It's like, just make a pivot table.

27
00:01:04.550 --> 00:01:06.500
And it's like, my gosh,
it's the scariest thing in the world.

28
00:01:06.500 --> 00:01:10.341
And it's actually not that bad,
once you break it down.

29
00:01:10.341 --> 00:01:11.380
Same with the charts.

30
00:01:11.380 --> 00:01:16.007
If you really kinda just like,
let's talk about the terminology first.

31
00:01:16.007 --> 00:01:16.807
What is a series?

32
00:01:16.807 --> 00:01:17.855
What is an axis?

33
00:01:17.855 --> 00:01:20.562
What is a value label thing?

34
00:01:20.562 --> 00:01:22.510
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Hey, guess what?

35
00:01:22.510 --> 00:01:24.507
We have a PowerPoint, so
I know what we're talking about, so.

36
00:01:24.507 --> 00:01:25.406
[LAUGH]
>> Well,

37
00:01:25.406 --> 00:01:26.950
I think it's funny you
bring up the terminology.

38
00:01:26.950 --> 00:01:31.240
I think that is probably
the very beginning of the,

39
00:01:31.240 --> 00:01:34.850
you start getting heart palpitations and
hesitations about doing Excel.

40
00:01:34.850 --> 00:01:36.790
Because it's got some strange terminology.

41
00:01:36.790 --> 00:01:40.690
Pivot table,
that just sounds like math to me.

42
00:01:40.690 --> 00:01:43.540
And that makes me have anxiety attacks.

43
00:01:43.540 --> 00:01:46.280
>> Yeah, and it's one of those,
okay, we need a report.

44
00:01:46.280 --> 00:01:49.310
You need to generate this now,
and it's like, what?

45
00:01:49.310 --> 00:01:54.854
And so it's a lot of, well,
I know what I would need it to look like.

46
00:01:54.854 --> 00:01:58.150
Chart needs to look like this, but
I can't make the numbers do it.

47
00:01:58.150 --> 00:01:59.900
And that can be a little
bit of a struggle.

48
00:01:59.900 --> 00:02:02.866
Now, of course, we're gonna have
perfect demonstration, where, look,

49
00:02:02.866 --> 00:02:04.030
everything works perfectly!

50
00:02:04.030 --> 00:02:06.223
>> That's right.
>> And in the real world,

51
00:02:06.223 --> 00:02:10.615
it really also comes down to,
is your data set up properly

52
00:02:10.615 --> 00:02:15.479
to be able to show the report that
your boss wanted two days ago?

53
00:02:15.479 --> 00:02:18.185
And you're just like,
I don't know how to do a chart so.

54
00:02:18.185 --> 00:02:19.239
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we're gonna try and

55
00:02:19.239 --> 00:02:20.821
just start from the very beginning.

56
00:02:20.821 --> 00:02:25.715
This is why we have our introduction to
charts in the particular topic of this

57
00:02:25.715 --> 00:02:26.570
series.

58
00:02:26.570 --> 00:02:28.441
And so we're gonna just start
getting familiar with this.

59
00:02:28.441 --> 00:02:30.640
So I do have a PowerPoint ready to go.

60
00:02:30.640 --> 00:02:32.239
It's called Parts of a Chart, and

61
00:02:32.239 --> 00:02:35.447
this is something that I've actually
used in a couple other series.

62
00:02:35.447 --> 00:02:39.232
So if it looks familiar,
you've seen it before.

63
00:02:39.232 --> 00:02:42.905
So now this is where, in this particular
slideshow we're talking about, okay,

64
00:02:42.905 --> 00:02:45.180
well, we could have
a table of information.

65
00:02:45.180 --> 00:02:48.920
Now, of course, in Excel
everything's in a table, in a sense.

66
00:02:48.920 --> 00:02:52.520
What I mean by table is we have
everything in columns and in rows.

67
00:02:52.520 --> 00:02:58.220
It is a spreadsheet application,
to clarify that formatting as a table.

68
00:02:58.220 --> 00:03:00.190
Tables in Excel are a little different.

69
00:03:00.190 --> 00:03:04.250
But if we're using the generic
terminology, that's what we've got.

70
00:03:04.250 --> 00:03:07.580
So if we could see, all right, well, it
looks like definitely Bishop sleeps more

71
00:03:07.580 --> 00:03:12.000
than Fuego, and
they both seem to play a decent amount.

72
00:03:12.000 --> 00:03:14.890
But it looks like Bishop's
got him won there and

73
00:03:14.890 --> 00:03:17.210
Fuego definitely likes to
meow more than Bishop.

74
00:03:17.210 --> 00:03:18.217
I'm looking at that.

75
00:03:18.217 --> 00:03:21.641
But wouldn't it be a lot easier
if we had some graphical

76
00:03:21.641 --> 00:03:25.737
representation of our data to say,
wow, well, then yeah,

77
00:03:25.737 --> 00:03:29.400
the orange bar is much bigger
than the blue bar right here?

78
00:03:29.400 --> 00:03:31.042
And then which one is the orange?

79
00:03:31.042 --> 00:03:32.673
Orange is Bishop, so

80
00:03:32.673 --> 00:03:37.491
a chart is really just a graphical
representation of our data.

81
00:03:37.491 --> 00:03:38.962
Just like we have have smart art,

82
00:03:38.962 --> 00:03:41.655
which is a graphical representation
of our data right here.

83
00:03:41.655 --> 00:03:44.525
So we can visually see what

84
00:03:44.525 --> 00:03:48.085
our information is trying
to tell us right here.

85
00:03:48.085 --> 00:03:51.855
So this is where we have,
this is a clustered column chart, and

86
00:03:51.855 --> 00:03:55.295
then you can see that we have
our series labels on there.

87
00:03:55.295 --> 00:03:58.544
We also have our different value axis and
we have our legend.

88
00:03:58.544 --> 00:04:03.540
See, I'm already using that terminology
if a chart right from the very beginning.

89
00:04:03.540 --> 00:04:04.700
But what is this doing?

90
00:04:04.700 --> 00:04:10.075
It is comparing the hours, or
really we're comparing Fuego and Bishop to

91
00:04:10.075 --> 00:04:15.900
each other in each category of sleeping,
and eating, playing, and meowing.

92
00:04:15.900 --> 00:04:18.320
So you could see that along the bottom.

93
00:04:19.390 --> 00:04:20.840
And how are we measuring this?

94
00:04:20.840 --> 00:04:24.490
Well, it says hours right over
there on the left-hand side and

95
00:04:24.490 --> 00:04:29.430
we have something at the top that says,
Activities Hours a Day.

96
00:04:29.430 --> 00:04:33.385
So all of these things are just going to
kinda help explain what this information,

97
00:04:33.385 --> 00:04:36.380
well, what we're actually looking at.

98
00:04:36.380 --> 00:04:40.107
So let's jump into some of that
terminology that we're going to be using

99
00:04:40.107 --> 00:04:44.031
within Excel, and really what Excel is
going to be forcing us to use in this.

100
00:04:44.031 --> 00:04:48.813
Everywhere where you see the orange,
that is known as a data series.

101
00:04:48.813 --> 00:04:54.240
It's a series of information that
has different points along the way.

102
00:04:54.240 --> 00:04:58.060
The 12 hours of sleep that
Bishop does is a point.

103
00:04:58.060 --> 00:05:00.860
The three hours that he eats,
that is in point.

104
00:05:00.860 --> 00:05:05.255
And you can see that we're trying to
correlate where that works within this

105
00:05:05.255 --> 00:05:06.448
tabular data with.

106
00:05:06.448 --> 00:05:10.420
This is more within PowerPoint.

107
00:05:10.420 --> 00:05:14.449
But you'll see it when we see
the example in Excel, that that column,

108
00:05:14.449 --> 00:05:18.428
Bishop is a column, Fuego is a column and
the activities is a column.

109
00:05:18.428 --> 00:05:21.187
And in the rows, you have the sleeping and
the eating, and so

110
00:05:21.187 --> 00:05:23.800
that's where you have the rows
going across the bottom.

111
00:05:23.800 --> 00:05:29.360
And the columns are the different, well,
in this sense, columns of the chart.

112
00:05:29.360 --> 00:05:32.480
So we have our value,
access, and category access,

113
00:05:32.480 --> 00:05:36.250
because those are the categories
of what we're comparing.

114
00:05:36.250 --> 00:05:40.190
The sleeping and
the eating of Fuego and Bishop, so

115
00:05:40.190 --> 00:05:44.050
that's what we need to
have across the top.

116
00:05:44.050 --> 00:05:48.720
Because we are working on an x and
a y-axis,

117
00:05:48.720 --> 00:05:53.360
or what they're saying is category
on the bottom, value on the left.

118
00:05:55.310 --> 00:06:00.030
Let's see what's on the next slide, and
then all sorts of parts of your chart.

119
00:06:00.030 --> 00:06:03.478
You have the chart's title, well,
that's pretty self-explanatory.

120
00:06:03.478 --> 00:06:04.688
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.
>> That's the thing up at the top.

121
00:06:04.688 --> 00:06:05.766
[LAUGH]
>> So

122
00:06:05.766 --> 00:06:08.395
tell me more about this
title of which you speak.

123
00:06:08.395 --> 00:06:11.030
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, the title is the title.

124
00:06:11.030 --> 00:06:11.685
>> It's at the top.

125
00:06:11.685 --> 00:06:12.475
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

126
00:06:12.475 --> 00:06:14.547
>> About the thing you're looking at.

127
00:06:14.547 --> 00:06:16.734
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Exactly, yeah, so

128
00:06:16.734 --> 00:06:18.720
we have the title, the legend.

129
00:06:18.720 --> 00:06:21.360
What does blue represent?

130
00:06:21.360 --> 00:06:23.250
What does orange represent?

131
00:06:23.250 --> 00:06:25.440
And that's what I'm looking at.

132
00:06:25.440 --> 00:06:28.580
And then, of course, we have an axis
title that this is the activity and

133
00:06:28.580 --> 00:06:31.130
the axis title here, where we have it.

134
00:06:31.130 --> 00:06:34.130
And I'm just kind of emphasizing
that the data series,

135
00:06:34.130 --> 00:06:39.150
the grid lines, and all of this is,
we're plotting this chart.

136
00:06:39.150 --> 00:06:42.423
So, this is the plot
area all around in here,

137
00:06:42.423 --> 00:06:45.361
which is different than the chart area.

138
00:06:45.361 --> 00:06:48.581
The whole box that everything lives, and

139
00:06:48.581 --> 00:06:52.450
all of these are selectable
items within a chart.

140
00:06:53.510 --> 00:06:58.407
And so, knowing what you want to format,
well, you gotta know where to click and

141
00:06:58.407 --> 00:06:59.932
what you want selected.

142
00:06:59.932 --> 00:07:04.861
So we have some nice references
right here to that terminology.

143
00:07:04.861 --> 00:07:09.384
The thing on the bottom, and I've seen
these types of things, I've seen charts

144
00:07:09.384 --> 00:07:13.724
that have this, well, table at the bottom
that gives you that information.

145
00:07:13.724 --> 00:07:14.940
This is known as a data table.

146
00:07:14.940 --> 00:07:17.704
Because while the bars will go ahead and

147
00:07:17.704 --> 00:07:22.320
represent, I can easily see that
Bishop sleeps more than Fuego.

148
00:07:22.320 --> 00:07:29.859
And these are all whole numbers, but
what if this was 12.8256 and 8.2584?

149
00:07:29.859 --> 00:07:35.386
That's where you might need to see
that information in its entirety,

150
00:07:35.386 --> 00:07:40.550
so you can add a data table to make
a little bit more sense out of it.

151
00:07:42.200 --> 00:07:44.340
But then you could also switch this.

152
00:07:44.340 --> 00:07:48.403
Now, this is just another way that
we could interpret this data.

153
00:07:48.403 --> 00:07:53.411
Instead of in one category
we're comparing the sleeping,

154
00:07:53.411 --> 00:07:57.228
eating and playing,
now we have it as Fuego.

155
00:07:57.228 --> 00:08:01.643
And all the things we're comparing is
the amount of sleep, eat, play and meow.

156
00:08:01.643 --> 00:08:04.905
So you could see that it's just It's
really just take the information and

157
00:08:04.905 --> 00:08:06.654
just flipping it on it's side, okay?

158
00:08:06.654 --> 00:08:11.632
So now you can kind of compare
Cats as the category rather than

159
00:08:11.632 --> 00:08:14.180
the Activity as the category.

160
00:08:14.180 --> 00:08:16.696
And I probably should've
changed that label right here,

161
00:08:16.696 --> 00:08:18.710
that it's not really
that activity anymore.

162
00:08:18.710 --> 00:08:21.480
It would be Cats, so [LAUGH].

163
00:08:21.480 --> 00:08:22.961
>> [LAUGH]
>> But, that's okay.

164
00:08:22.961 --> 00:08:25.701
We'll pretend that didn't happen [LAUGH].

165
00:08:25.701 --> 00:08:30.130
We'll have the line graphs, cuz there's
all sorts of different types of charts.

166
00:08:30.130 --> 00:08:31.857
We have our clustered column here.

167
00:08:31.857 --> 00:08:34.830
And then we have a line graph.

168
00:08:34.830 --> 00:08:37.870
Graph and charts,
those are kinda used interchangeably.

169
00:08:37.870 --> 00:08:39.430
We don't really call it a line chart.

170
00:08:39.430 --> 00:08:41.200
At least that's not how
I remember doing this.

171
00:08:41.200 --> 00:08:45.070
Cuz I remember having to do this
in school and put the little dots.

172
00:08:45.070 --> 00:08:46.526
And then draw all the lines like that.

173
00:08:46.526 --> 00:08:49.070
>> Yeah, I think they just called it
a line graph where I went to school.

174
00:08:49.070 --> 00:08:49.810
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah.

175
00:08:49.810 --> 00:08:50.760
>> Yeah, graph, chart.

176
00:08:50.760 --> 00:08:51.506
>> Chart, same thing.

177
00:08:51.506 --> 00:08:52.554
>> Same thing.
>> Six of one.

178
00:08:52.554 --> 00:08:54.514
>> Half dozen or the other
>> Some other.

179
00:08:54.514 --> 00:08:55.323
>> Did I say it right?

180
00:08:55.323 --> 00:08:55.937
>> You did, actually [LAUGH].

181
00:08:55.937 --> 00:08:56.858
>> Yes [LAUGH]!

182
00:08:56.858 --> 00:08:58.297
>> So proud of you.

183
00:08:58.297 --> 00:08:58.897
>> Score [LAUGH]!

184
00:08:58.897 --> 00:09:02.658
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so we have different ways,

185
00:09:02.658 --> 00:09:04.509
and this has specific style.

186
00:09:04.509 --> 00:09:09.442
We've talked a lot about formatting
graphable elements with styles

187
00:09:09.442 --> 00:09:11.660
in our Excel advanced series.

188
00:09:11.660 --> 00:09:16.026
So all the same things that you can do
with a shape or an image where you can,

189
00:09:16.026 --> 00:09:18.293
well I guess we'll stay with shapes.

190
00:09:18.293 --> 00:09:22.760
Fills, outlines, the effect where you
can put drop shadows, you can put glows.

191
00:09:22.760 --> 00:09:24.730
You can make anything 3D.

192
00:09:24.730 --> 00:09:28.020
All of that applies,
because this is a graphical element.

193
00:09:28.020 --> 00:09:33.150
This is a piece of art, if we'll call it,
to go ahead and show the information.

194
00:09:34.450 --> 00:09:36.739
Then here's another type of chart
that we see a lot of times.

195
00:09:36.739 --> 00:09:40.080
This would be a pie chart, or a pie graph.

196
00:09:40.080 --> 00:09:42.526
And this does have some
styles applied to it.

197
00:09:42.526 --> 00:09:44.440
You still have a legend.

198
00:09:44.440 --> 00:09:49.736
But when this time what we're doing is
you're really only comparing one series,

199
00:09:49.736 --> 00:09:54.659
one category, that Fuego, where you
don't have Fuego and Bishop in here.

200
00:09:54.659 --> 00:10:00.440
So pie charts is just one
thing that has pieces of it.

201
00:10:00.440 --> 00:10:02.664
So you could see that we're
looking at the activity here.

202
00:10:02.664 --> 00:10:07.560
And I also have some data labels on
here of what is the actual value.

203
00:10:07.560 --> 00:10:11.960
And then what percentage
of the whole that is.

204
00:10:11.960 --> 00:10:12.700
And guess what?

205
00:10:12.700 --> 00:10:14.010
I didn't calculate that.

206
00:10:14.010 --> 00:10:15.191
I didn't do any of that math.

207
00:10:15.191 --> 00:10:16.486
Luckily, Excel does it for me.

208
00:10:16.486 --> 00:10:19.556
All I have to do is check off a little
check box of Use Percentages.

209
00:10:19.556 --> 00:10:21.360
Like, yes, no math [LAUGH].

210
00:10:21.360 --> 00:10:25.252
And then of course we have
an exploding pie right here.

211
00:10:25.252 --> 00:10:28.596
That's what it's actually
called the amount of explosion.

212
00:10:28.596 --> 00:10:30.710
And one little piece right here.

213
00:10:30.710 --> 00:10:34.570
And so we can see different ways
that we can take our data labels.

214
00:10:34.570 --> 00:10:38.798
Instead of having them here in
the middle with a specific style,

215
00:10:38.798 --> 00:10:40.688
we have them on the outside.

216
00:10:40.688 --> 00:10:42.658
And then there's also changes
where the legend goes.

217
00:10:42.658 --> 00:10:47.400
So you can see that you can start moving
around these different components.

218
00:10:47.400 --> 00:10:51.457
But again, knowing that these things
out here are known as data labels.

219
00:10:51.457 --> 00:10:53.498
And knowing that this thing
down here is a legend.

220
00:10:53.498 --> 00:10:55.996
And you're just kinda
getting that terminology,

221
00:10:55.996 --> 00:10:58.480
is going to be really important.

222
00:10:58.480 --> 00:11:01.652
Now the nice thing is that you gonna
have a lot of help along the way,

223
00:11:01.652 --> 00:11:04.614
when you start inserting charts and
you start formatting it.

224
00:11:04.614 --> 00:11:08.976

where do I find that?

476
00:25:38.541 --> 00:25:43.530
And if I wanted to, you could change it to
the different ones with the horizontal.

477
00:25:43.530 --> 00:25:50.900
Or you can get into a custom alignment,
but let's see how we can get into that.

478
00:25:50.900 --> 00:25:53.499
Well, it's not giving me
the option to do that.

479
00:25:53.499 --> 00:25:57.752
Well, hm, we'll have to come back and
figure that out.

480
00:25:57.752 --> 00:26:03.589
[LAUGH] But, it's right there.

481
00:26:03.589 --> 00:26:06.614
[LAUGH] [LAUGH] Custom angle.

482
00:26:06.614 --> 00:26:08.512
So to get to that custom angle,

483
00:26:08.512 --> 00:26:12.832
we do have to make sure that the text
direction's back to horizontal.

484
00:26:12.832 --> 00:26:16.518
Cuz if you had changed it to something
else, if you had made it rotate,

485
00:26:16.518 --> 00:26:19.110
then the field isn't
available to you there.

486
00:26:19.110 --> 00:26:22.252
So if you go back to horizontal,
cuz maybe you wanna go ahead and

487
00:26:22.252 --> 00:26:25.705
put that as a 45 degree angle,
we probably have to do the other one.

488
00:26:25.705 --> 00:26:27.340
Oo, this is where we're
gonna have to get some math.

489
00:26:27.340 --> 00:26:27.844
You know what?

490
00:26:27.844 --> 00:26:29.145
Let's just go ahead and
make those bumpy arrows.

491
00:26:29.145 --> 00:26:30.134
[LAUGH] Yeah, look at that.

492
00:26:30.134 --> 00:26:31.135
There we go.

493
00:26:31.135 --> 00:26:33.543
Just hold it down and let it move.

494
00:26:33.543 --> 00:26:35.873
Yeah, well,
then actually that would be a -45.

495
00:26:35.873 --> 00:26:36.773
Okay, there, see,

496
00:26:36.773 --> 00:26:40.360
as soon I started doing the bump,
he's like, just put a negative on it.

497
00:26:40.360 --> 00:26:41.169
Yay math!
All right, so

498
00:26:41.169 --> 00:26:43.079
that's where you can
change the angle of it.

499
00:26:43.079 --> 00:26:48.059
But again, more options in your
different items within your charts.

500
00:26:48.059 --> 00:26:50.219
Come over to that Format Task pane,

501
00:26:50.219 --> 00:26:54.684
and you could've gotten it from
right-clicking on any element in here.

502
00:26:54.684 --> 00:26:58.820
I could've just been on the plot area,
and it's gonna bring this up.

503
00:26:58.820 --> 00:27:01.540
And you know now that we have that
dropdown to change the different

504
00:27:01.540 --> 00:27:02.683
places where we need to be.

505
00:27:02.683 --> 00:27:05.773
Okay, now let's go ahead and
close this task pane for now.

506
00:27:05.773 --> 00:27:06.917
Just a few more things that,

507
00:27:06.917 --> 00:27:09.739
I know you're giving me that signal
we need to start wrapping this up.

508
00:27:09.739 --> 00:27:12.800
We're coming to the end of our episode.

509
00:27:12.800 --> 00:27:15.630
We do have this switch between rows and
columns now.

510
00:27:16.750 --> 00:27:20.189
That's really easy to where now
we're going to be using Fuego and

511
00:27:20.189 --> 00:27:24.264
comparing his different activities,
so just turning the rows and columns.

512
00:27:24.264 --> 00:27:27.865
We also, we'll come back over
here to this Select Data.

513
00:27:27.865 --> 00:27:30.978
Let's go over these in another
episode to where I can

514
00:27:30.978 --> 00:27:34.463
really kind of accentuate why
we might wanna come to here.

515
00:27:34.463 --> 00:27:37.583
Because this is a very simple and
easy example of like, well,

516
00:27:37.583 --> 00:27:39.093
everything looks just fine.

517
00:27:39.093 --> 00:27:42.799
I don't need to come in here
to pick different things.

518
00:27:42.799 --> 00:27:47.255
But if information isn't as beautiful,
we organized as this,

519
00:27:47.255 --> 00:27:51.886
this is where this dialog box will
come into play a little bit more.

520
00:27:51.886 --> 00:27:55.870
So we'll come back around
to that in another episode.

521
00:27:55.870 --> 00:27:59.480
We could also come into where
you wanna move the chart.

522
00:27:59.480 --> 00:28:03.020
Right now, it's just an element
within this worksheet.

523
00:28:03.020 --> 00:28:05.865
But if I wanted,
I can make it its all by itself,

524
00:28:05.865 --> 00:28:10.380
get his own sheet, let's move it on over
there and then, there we go, perfect.

525
00:28:10.380 --> 00:28:15.295
So now this is where maybe if I wanted to
help print this out, just have it on one

526
00:28:15.295 --> 00:28:20.990
worksheet, as opposed to an element within
that worksheet, that could be really nice.

527
00:28:20.990 --> 00:28:25.480
And then if you really wanted to come
over here and change the type of chart,

528
00:28:25.480 --> 00:28:29.710
you can make it into a bar chart or
into one of those line charts.

529
00:28:29.710 --> 00:28:34.980
Sometime information doesn't lend itself
to going into other charts very well.

530
00:28:34.980 --> 00:28:38.294
Like this wouldn't necessarily be,
oo, that's a weird-looking pie piece.

531
00:28:38.294 --> 00:28:40.321
[LAUGH] [LAUGH] So
we'll just keep it with the column.

532
00:28:40.321 --> 00:28:46.510
Maybe we can throw it into a bar chart,
just to see who's winning there.

533
00:28:46.510 --> 00:28:50.824
And the last thing I'd like to just
point out, and this is basic charts and

534
00:28:50.824 --> 00:28:51.879
how to format it.

535
00:28:51.879 --> 00:28:55.307
There's all these little buttons
over here on the right-hand side.

536
00:28:56.346 --> 00:28:57.760
Just different places that you can go to,

537
00:28:57.760 --> 00:29:03.020
to add a chart element,
as opposed to going on to the Design tab.

538
00:29:03.020 --> 00:29:06.900
You could also come in to the Format
Options, where you can do some of

539
00:29:06.900 --> 00:29:11.580
different styles or go right into
the different color blocks and everything.

540
00:29:11.580 --> 00:29:15.380
So you can quickly pick from there,
rather than going to the tab.

541
00:29:15.380 --> 00:29:18.208
But the last one right here,
the filtering,

542
00:29:18.208 --> 00:29:23.055
is to where maybe I don't want to see
the sleeping and eating for some reason.

543
00:29:23.055 --> 00:29:26.008
I only want to see the meows,
so I was like,

544
00:29:26.008 --> 00:29:29.717
I don't want to change
the data from the select data.

545
00:29:29.717 --> 00:29:31.521
I just wanna filter it out.

546
00:29:31.521 --> 00:29:34.883
So what you can do is you can turn on and
off these checkboxes.

547
00:29:34.883 --> 00:29:40.022
But the things that you have to remember
is if I wanted to not show sleep and

548
00:29:40.022 --> 00:29:42.968
not show meow, to make these apply, hm,

549
00:29:42.968 --> 00:29:46.524
what do you think you're
gonna click down there?

550
00:29:46.524 --> 00:29:48.290
Yep, the Apply button.

551
00:29:48.290 --> 00:29:49.534
Apply button?
[LAUGH] Yeah, and

552
00:29:49.534 --> 00:29:51.841
so now you're just saying,
I don't want part of this.

553
00:29:51.841 --> 00:29:54.666
This is something that we did with tables,
right?

554
00:29:54.666 --> 00:29:57.499
We could say,
I only want to see these certain things.

555
00:29:57.499 --> 00:30:01.871
So filtering out the information within
your chart, that can be really handy.

556
00:30:01.871 --> 00:30:06.194
Now as soon as you're like, oo, wouldn't
that be nice to show buttons on doing

557
00:30:06.194 --> 00:30:10.581
different things, you're starting to get
into more pivot charts and maybe some

558
00:30:10.581 --> 00:30:14.600
slicers and some different options
that we will cover in other episodes.

559
00:30:14.600 --> 00:30:18.950
But I at least wanted to point out those
little buttons for you right there.

560
00:30:18.950 --> 00:30:23.710
And I believe that covers everything
in just some basic charts,

561
00:30:23.710 --> 00:30:27.760
inserting it and formatting the different
pieces, and that's what I got.

562
00:30:27.760 --> 00:30:28.400
All right, well, Vonne,

563
00:30:28.400 --> 00:30:31.300
I feel like you've at least given us
enough to get started with charts.

564
00:30:31.300 --> 00:30:34.430
I can actually insert a chart
with some data inside of it and

565
00:30:34.430 --> 00:30:35.560
it will do something.

566
00:30:35.560 --> 00:30:37.670
It will look like a chart, and
that's always a good thing.

567
00:30:37.670 --> 00:30:39.180
Now you can start getting your feet wet.

568
00:30:39.180 --> 00:30:40.984
Start playing with buttons,
clicking things, see what they do.

569
00:30:40.984 --> 00:30:45.317
The good news is that you can always
create a practice chart that you can

570
00:30:45.317 --> 00:30:48.411
destroy, or
make as beautiful as you would like.

571
00:30:48.411 --> 00:30:52.770
And Vonne has given us a lot of cool
tools in which we can do that already.

572
00:30:52.770 --> 00:30:57.581
So go out there, young Excel Padawans,
and learn and play and have a good time.

573
00:30:57.581 --> 00:31:00.374
Vonne, thanks for showing us how
we can play with our charts.

574
00:31:00.374 --> 00:31:02.354
And I know that you've got more for
us down the road and

575
00:31:02.354 --> 00:31:04.115
how we can get a little
more advanced with that.

576
00:31:04.115 --> 00:31:05.690
It's gonna be a lot of fun.

577
00:31:05.690 --> 00:31:06.900
And we do thank you for joining us.

578
00:31:06.900 --> 00:31:09.840
We thank our audience for joining us
as well, but guess what, everyone?

579
00:31:09.840 --> 00:31:11.840
It is that time for us to sign off.

580
00:31:11.840 --> 00:31:14.230
For OfficeProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

581
00:31:14.230 --> 00:31:15.478
And I'm Vonne Smith.
And we'll see you next time.

582
00:31:15.478 --> 00:31:22.720
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne demonstrate how you can create a Chart from disconnected or noncontiguous data. Here they will walk you through the steps needed to select and connect the noncontiguous data you want to use to create a chart.
episodes.title: Create Charts from Noncontiguous Data
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.121 --> 00:00:14.000
All right, greetings everyone and

3
00:00:14.000 --> 00:00:17.540
welcome back to another great
episode of Office Pro TV.

4
00:00:17.540 --> 00:00:20.750
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and in today's
episode we are moving on with more in our

5
00:00:20.750 --> 00:00:23.230
Excel charts and pivot table series.

6
00:00:23.230 --> 00:00:25.920
It's gonna be a lot of fun,
and joining us in the studio,

7
00:00:25.920 --> 00:00:29.970
our resident expert on that very topic,
our one and only, Ms. Vonne Smith.

8
00:00:29.970 --> 00:00:30.780
Vonne, welcome back.

9
00:00:30.780 --> 00:00:31.620
How are you today?

10
00:00:31.620 --> 00:00:33.050
>> I'm doing fantastic.

11
00:00:33.050 --> 00:00:33.760
>> Good.
>> We're here

12
00:00:33.760 --> 00:00:38.110
to talk about creating charts
from a non-contiguous data set.

13
00:00:38.110 --> 00:00:40.880
And that's kind of a mouthful right,
[LAUGH] yeah, yes.

14
00:00:40.880 --> 00:00:44.183
It's one of those, if you don't
know what non-contiguous set means.

15
00:00:44.183 --> 00:00:45.877
>> Non-contigilicious what?.

16
00:00:45.877 --> 00:00:49.450
>> It's a really long word like,
I don't know what that is.

17
00:00:49.450 --> 00:00:54.320
Well, have been using that particular
phrase throughout our Excel series about

18
00:00:54.320 --> 00:00:57.270
a contiguous range of cells would be
things that are right next to each other.

19
00:00:57.270 --> 00:00:58.578
That they're all touching.

20
00:00:58.578 --> 00:01:04.100
Well, a non-contiguous set would be
something that's not next to each other.

21
00:01:04.100 --> 00:01:06.726
>> So A1 and F13, right.

22
00:01:06.726 --> 00:01:08.846
>> Yeah, exactly, yeah, so
they're not next to each other.

23
00:01:08.846 --> 00:01:12.557
And when we were creating a basic
chart and we went ahead and

24
00:01:12.557 --> 00:01:16.520
said, look let's just select it and
poof, it's just done.

25
00:01:16.520 --> 00:01:19.972
It doesn't always work that easily.

26
00:01:19.972 --> 00:01:22.532
>> Yeah, cuz what if I want cell A1 and
F14, and

27
00:01:22.532 --> 00:01:26.320
they have two pieces of data that
I wanna put inside of my chart.

28
00:01:26.320 --> 00:01:28.060
How the heck do I make that happen?

29
00:01:28.060 --> 00:01:29.625
>> And that's why we've made this episode.

30
00:01:29.625 --> 00:01:30.560
[LAUGH]
>> That's why we're doing

31
00:01:30.560 --> 00:01:31.140
this thing, right?

32
00:01:31.140 --> 00:01:31.800
>> That's why we're here.

33
00:01:31.800 --> 00:01:36.960
So I have a couple of different examples
in a file that I'd like to just kinda just

34
00:01:36.960 --> 00:01:40.910
run through them to give you different
ideas of, the data's across or

35
00:01:40.910 --> 00:01:41.940
it's down the side.

36
00:01:41.940 --> 00:01:43.380
And, that just didn't work at all.

37
00:01:43.380 --> 00:01:45.360
[LAUGH] And
different ways that I can fix it.

38
00:01:45.360 --> 00:01:47.880
So why don't we jump on
down into this file?

39
00:01:47.880 --> 00:01:52.758
And just to recap from our other episode
that we had done where we just had to,

40
00:01:52.758 --> 00:01:56.150
I think it was insert and
format a basic chart.

41
00:01:56.150 --> 00:01:59.700
We took this data right here,
we selected it, we went to Insert.

42
00:01:59.700 --> 00:02:02.680
We said cluster column chart and
then poof there it is.

43
00:02:02.680 --> 00:02:03.980
We got everything right there.

44
00:02:03.980 --> 00:02:08.640
We got our Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday,
Fuego, Bishop cuz all of the labels that I

45
00:02:08.640 --> 00:02:13.770
wanted for my series, that would be
like Fuego, Bishop, Pumpkin, and Puma.

46
00:02:13.770 --> 00:02:16.320
Those are our series and
then the category,

47
00:02:16.320 --> 00:02:20.680
that's our horizontal axis is across
the bottom, it just knew to go ahead and

48
00:02:20.680 --> 00:02:23.820
just pick it all and
it was easy and it was fine.

49
00:02:23.820 --> 00:02:27.106
And well, great,
what if it's not like that?

50
00:02:27.106 --> 00:02:32.011
So let's say I want to chart our daily
totals, all right, so this is where I want

51
00:02:32.011 --> 00:02:37.153
to say what are the totals for Monday,
Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday.

52
00:02:37.153 --> 00:02:41.840
So this is only gonna be one series.

53
00:02:41.840 --> 00:02:45.970
It's not going to be multiples where
we have Fuego and Bishop and Pumpkin.

54
00:02:45.970 --> 00:02:48.230
It's just gonna be the daily totals.

55
00:02:48.230 --> 00:02:50.880
It's easier if we go ahead and
just visualize it and see it.

56
00:02:50.880 --> 00:02:53.710
So I'm gonna go ahead and
select Daily Totals.

57
00:02:53.710 --> 00:02:58.130
And I am grabbing this cuz
it does have a label here.

58
00:02:58.130 --> 00:02:59.040
So, grab that.

59
00:03:00.370 --> 00:03:04.137
And if I say Insert >
Cluster column chart.

60
00:03:04.137 --> 00:03:05.940
All right, well, it's doing it.

61
00:03:05.940 --> 00:03:09.558
And I can say that this is Monday,
Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday.

62
00:03:09.558 --> 00:03:12.940
But it just says, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.

63
00:03:12.940 --> 00:03:16.080
It doesn't actually give like the days,
the week.

64
00:03:16.080 --> 00:03:20.547
I'm just gonna move down just a little
bit so we can kinda see that.

65
00:03:20.547 --> 00:03:24.505
So it's close but not all the way.

66
00:03:24.505 --> 00:03:30.285
So I need to be able to modify
the data that's in this chart.

67
00:03:30.285 --> 00:03:33.675
So we've talked about this Select Data
button that we went to a couple times

68
00:03:33.675 --> 00:03:34.285
in the episode.

69
00:03:34.285 --> 00:03:36.795
But now we're gonna really
kinda come into this a lot.

70
00:03:36.795 --> 00:03:42.110
Because this is where the only series
that I have are the daily totals, and

71
00:03:42.110 --> 00:03:45.910
it's telling me that, and it's actually
putting that in the chart title.

72
00:03:45.910 --> 00:03:49.957
So that's fine, but this category access,
it just says 1, 2, 3, 4,

73
00:03:49.957 --> 00:03:55.060
5, so I need to go out,
into my worksheet somewhere and

74
00:03:55.060 --> 00:04:00.460
tell it, where are the category labels,
where do they live.

75
00:04:00.460 --> 00:04:02.960
Well it's the Monday, Tuesday,
Wednesday, Thursday, Friday.

76
00:04:02.960 --> 00:04:06.410
So you're just gonna come over
here to your category axis.

77
00:04:06.410 --> 00:04:08.120
You're gonna click Edit.

78
00:04:08.120 --> 00:04:10.300
And now it says, well,
tell me where this is.

79
00:04:10.300 --> 00:04:12.180
I have a cursor in that box.

80
00:04:12.180 --> 00:04:17.630
You just take your white plus sign and
you select the cells.

81
00:04:17.630 --> 00:04:21.610
And, look at there, now it went ahead and
labelled everything I needed to do.

82
00:04:21.610 --> 00:04:25.519
So sometimes you have to kinda force
the information because the labels weren't

83
00:04:25.519 --> 00:04:27.600
right next to it in that contiguous range.

84
00:04:27.600 --> 00:04:32.700
It's non-contiguous so I had to come
in here and fix it a little bit.

85
00:04:32.700 --> 00:04:35.129
So that's the easiest way
that we can do that and

86
00:04:35.129 --> 00:04:36.844
it is exactly what I needed to do.

87
00:04:36.844 --> 00:04:41.200
If I click OK now I have my chart.

88
00:04:41.200 --> 00:04:46.029
Sometimes just to make sure that yeah
this is the actual information that I'm

89
00:04:46.029 --> 00:04:49.223
wanting to have, what I'll do,
I'll go ahead and

90
00:04:49.223 --> 00:04:53.782
put on a data table with that and
just double check, whoops okay, undo.

91
00:04:53.782 --> 00:04:58.329
Yeah that's 1, 40, 56,
yeah it's pulling the right information,

92
00:04:58.329 --> 00:05:02.510
because sometimes when you're
looking at just the visuals.

93
00:05:02.510 --> 00:05:05.330
It's like, is that actually right?

94
00:05:05.330 --> 00:05:06.430
I wanna make sure.

95
00:05:06.430 --> 00:05:09.250
So putting on that data table can
always confirm that with you.

96
00:05:09.250 --> 00:05:15.330
And then now I have it right across here,
and since it has things like $104.13,

97
00:05:15.330 --> 00:05:20.560
it's probably good to put that data table
on there so it has the actual value in it.

98
00:05:20.560 --> 00:05:21.960
>> So Vaughan, really quick question here,

99
00:05:21.960 --> 00:05:25.390
you've got your cool little chart
going on, and you're grabbing data.

100
00:05:25.390 --> 00:05:30.550
From all over your spreadsheet in
Excel and it's non-contiguous,

101
00:05:30.550 --> 00:05:32.160
because that's the whole
purpose of this show.

102
00:05:32.160 --> 00:05:34.050
If I wanted to just grab anything,

103
00:05:34.050 --> 00:05:37.510
are we basically just watching
the same thing over and over again?

104
00:05:37.510 --> 00:05:39.470
We're doing the same steps to do that?

105
00:05:39.470 --> 00:05:40.600
Is that what happens?

106
00:05:40.600 --> 00:05:43.988
>> I think what you're asking is can
I just grab some of these cells and

107
00:05:43.988 --> 00:05:46.784
grab some of these cells and
just make a chart out of it?

108
00:05:46.784 --> 00:05:50.675
>> Yeah, if I had a spreadsheet
that had attributes of people,

109
00:05:50.675 --> 00:05:55.250
Vonne, on one side, and
Daniel on the other, size, weight, shape,

110
00:05:55.250 --> 00:05:58.338
color, hair, no hair, I'm losing mine but.

111
00:05:58.338 --> 00:06:00.260
>> [LAUGH]
>> We wanted to compare that,

112
00:06:00.260 --> 00:06:00.930

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explain and show you how to create a pie chart in Excel. Specific topics covered here includes: labels, number formats, styles, series options, donut pie, pie in pie, sort sheet, format data series, data label options, and second plot size.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore working with Sparklines and Timelines in Excel 2016. Here you will see how to enable and use Sparklines to quickly see graphical data for data in a worksheet, insert Timelines to chart the history of a data-set, and use Slicers to quickly modify edit the viewed data.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore and explain the use and function of Pivot Tables. Here they will define what a Pivot Table is, when/where/why they're used, available options when using them, and deleting them when necessary.

00:30:00.830 --> 00:30:02.060
hit the Clear All button.

657
00:30:02.060 --> 00:30:06.540
So again, kind of convoluted
to get it all the way gone.

658
00:30:06.540 --> 00:30:09.280
But I just wanted to show you cuz that
was one that always threw me off.

659
00:30:09.280 --> 00:30:10.440
>> Yeah.
>> So I wanted to show you.

660
00:30:10.440 --> 00:30:13.430
So again, just basics of pivot tables.

661
00:30:13.430 --> 00:30:18.080
Pivot tables can go pretty high up and
how you're gonna be reporting your data.

662
00:30:18.080 --> 00:30:20.920
And you can import it from other places,
I mean, you can get a little crazy.

663
00:30:20.920 --> 00:30:25.795
And like you said, the chart, well, a
chart's just charting that information, so

664
00:30:25.795 --> 00:30:28.825
you just go and
say make a chart out of this and

665
00:30:28.825 --> 00:30:32.170
it does the same thing as being able to-
>> Does it make that noise?

666
00:30:32.170 --> 00:30:33.190
>> Yeah, [NOISE] just like that, so.

667
00:30:33.190 --> 00:30:34.709
>> Trademark that before
Microsoft grabs it.

668
00:30:34.709 --> 00:30:39.250
>> Yeah, well, so that's our basic
pivot tables, and I feel we're gonna

669

670
00:30:44.240 --> 00:30:48.650
to do things and taking it maybe just
another level up from the basics.

671
00:30:48.650 --> 00:30:49.570
>> Well Vonne, I appreciate

672

that you didn't chuck us into
the deep end of the pool.

673
00:30:51.300 --> 00:30:55.900
I've still got my floaties on, so I'm
not ready for that deep water quite yet.

674

But we were able to get our feet
wet inside of pivot tables.

675
00:30:59.480 --> 00:31:00.320
They're very simple.

676
00:31:00.320 --> 00:31:02.640
Very easy, and very cool to play with.

677
00:31:02.640 --> 00:31:03.620
It wasn't too difficult.

678
00:31:03.620 --> 00:31:07.100
I don't think it was beyond anybody's
here scope of understanding, so

679
00:31:07.100 --> 00:31:08.300
get in there and play with them.

680
00:31:08.300 --> 00:31:09.330
Manipulate that data.

00:31:09.330 --> 00:31:14.150
Make those pivot tables do something

00:31:14.150 --> 00:31:15.440
give you a cool output.

00:31:15.440 --> 00:31:16.940
So they are a lot of fun that way.

00:31:16.940 --> 00:31:19.090
Vonne, we do appreciate you time and

We do thank our good audience for

That's right, we're there yet again.

00:31:25.370 --> 00:31:26.920

00:31:30.052 --> 00:31:31.761

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne demonstrate how to create a basic Pivot Chart in Excel 2016. Here you'll see how to insert a Pivot Chart from a Pivot Table, look at series vs.categories, adding data labels, chart/table filters, changing source data, multiple charts, using the slicer, moving charts to separate sheets, and deleting tables.
episodes.title: Create a Basic Pivot Chart
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

00:00:16.984 --> 00:00:20.070

It's one of those yes but

a pivot chart, and I'm probably gonna

columns, you take that and

00:01:40.840 --> 00:01:42.350
We've gotta take this and

And it's all dynamic, it never changes

41
00:02:19.058 --> 00:02:20.326
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's the same but different,

42
00:02:20.326 --> 00:02:21.156

>> Yeah, [LAUGH] so

And I have the same file that we were

00:07:57.396 --> 00:07:58.810

00:08:09.540 --> 00:08:12.680

Cuz remember we're doing
